'''Lacy Gibson''' (May 1, 1936 – April 11, 2011)<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2011.html |title=2011 January to June |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter. He most notably recorded the songs, "My Love Is Real" and "Switchy Titchy", and in a long and varied career worked with [[Buddy Guy]] and [[Son Seals]].<ref name="Dead"/>

One commentator noted that Gibson "developed a large and varied repertoire after long stays with numerous bands, many recording sessions, and performances in Chicago nightclubs".<ref name="Encyc"/>

==Biography==
Gibson was born in [[Salisbury, North Carolina]], [[United States]],<ref name="Dead"/> but relocated with his family to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], in 1949.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p79846|pure_url=yes}}|title=Lacy Gibson |author=Bill Dahl |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 12, 2011}}</ref> Initially, he was taught guitar playing by his mother.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/News/lacy-gibson-0413-2011/ |title=Chicago Blues Guitarist Lacy Gibson Dies |author=Bryan Wawzenek |date=April 13, 2011 |work= |publisher=Gibson.com |accessdate= October 12, 2011}}</ref>

His early influences included [[Sunnyland Slim]], [[Muddy Waters]], [[Lefty Bates]], [[Matt Murphy (blues guitarist)|Matt Murphy]], and [[Wayne Bennett (blues guitarist)|Wayne Bennett]]. Gibson's earliest work was as a [[session musician]], playing mainly [[rhythm guitar]]. In 1963 alone, he recorded backing for [[Willie Mabon]], [[Billy "The Kid" Emerson]] and [[Buddy Guy]].<ref name="AMG"/>

Gibson's own recording debut was also in 1963 with [[Chess Records]], who recorded his song "My Love Is Real", with Buddy Guy on guitar.<ref name="Reuters"/>  The track remained unreleased at that time, and when it was finally issued, initial pressings credited the work to Guy. Two self-released singles followed, before Gibson recorded his debut album, ''Wishing Ring'' in 1971.<ref name="Disc"/><ref name="Reuters">{{cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/04/12/uk-lacygibson-idUKTRE73B5VB20110412 |title=Chicago blues musician Lacy Gibson dead at 74 |author=Andrew Stern |date=April 12, 2011 |work= |publisher=Reuters.com |accessdate=October 12, 2011}}</ref>  It was released on [[El Saturn Records]], which was partly owned by Gibson's then brother-in-law, [[Sun Ra]].<ref name="AMG"/>  The family connection continued when Ra recorded Gibson's co-written song, "I'm Gonna Unmask the Batman".<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lacy-gibson-mn0000118546/songs |title=Lacy Gibson | Songs |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>

In 1977, [[Ralph Bass]] [[record producer|produced]] another Gibson album, although this was not released until [[Delmark Records]] did the honors in 1996.  His following work with [[Son Seals]] was heard on Seal's 1978 ''[[Live and Burning]]'' album.<ref name="AMG"/> [[Alligator Records]] then included four tracks by Gibson on their 1980 ''Living Chicago Blues, Vol. 3'' [[compilation album]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/living-chicago-blues-vol-3-mw0000269958 |title=Living Chicago Blues, Vol. 3 - Various Artists | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>

Gibson released ''Switchy Titchy'' in 1982 on the [[Netherlands]]-based Black Magic Records label.<ref name="Encyc">{{cite book
| first= Gérard
| last= Herzhaft et al
| year= 1997
| title= Encyclopedia of the blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= The University of Arkansas Press 
| location= Fayetteville, Arkansas
| isbn= 1-55728-452-0
| page= 75}}</ref> His appearances after the release were reduced due to health problems, but he performed locally around Chicago, both on his own or backing [[Billy Boy Arnold]] and [[Big Time Sarah]]. Despite the reduction in his engagements, Gibson played at the [[Chicago Blues Festival]] in 2004.<ref name="AMG"/> Gibson also operated the Chicago after-hours [[nightclub]] "Ann's Love Nest" with his wife, for whom it was named.<ref name="Reuters"/> 

Gibson died of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] in Chicago in April 2011, aged 74.<ref name="Dead"/><ref name="Disc">{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Lacy+Gibson |title=Lacy Gibson |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Discogs.com |accessdate=October 12, 2011}}</ref>
